cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d'Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: Austrian Lloyd
div.p: Weekly Mail Steamers from ALEXANDRIA to BRINDISI TIRESTE (VENICE), leave Saturdays at 4 p.m. having connection in Brindisi with the Express train on Tuesday morning to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London. Arrival at Trieste on Wednesday about 11 a.m. A Train de Luxe leaves the same evening, 6.35 p.m. for Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussels, Ostende and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5.12 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Steamers from Alexandria to Trieste via Brindisi leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m.
Syria-Caramanian Line. Port Said, Jaffa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Alexandretta, Mersina, alternate Mondays: August 5, 19; Sept. 2, 16, 30; Oct. 14, 28; Nov. 11, 25; Dec. 9, 23: 4 p.m.
Syria-Cyprus Line. Beyrout, Limassol, Larnace, Mersina: alternate Tuesdays: Aug. 13, 27; Sept. 10, 24; Oct. 8, 22; Nov. 5, 19; Dec. 3, 17, 31, 4 p.m.
N.B.-During the present Quarantine in Syrian Ports against arrival from Egypt there is no connection between these lines and Alexandria on the outward voyage.
Far Eastern Lines. Sailing from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, (accelerated Service) on or about Aug. 8; Sept. 7; Oct. 7, 22; Nov. 7, 22; Dec. 7, 22.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon & Calcutta. Aug. 18; Sept. 18; Oct. 18; Nov. 18; Dec. 18.
To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hongkong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobe, Sept. 3; Oct. 4; Nov. 3; Dec. 4; Jan. 3 (1908).

div.head: Photographers. REISER & BINDER Photographers.
div.p: 26848 Alexandria & Cairo. 4-12 906
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.
N. SPATHIS, Agent.
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.

Monday, January 20, 1908.

div.head: A TRIUMPH OF BRITISH BRIDGE-BUILDERS
div.p: The new road bridges over the Nile at Cairo, says "Engineering”, are now completed, have been tested, and will be opened in a few dayo for tramway, vehicular, and pedestrian traffic. Our contemporary publishes illustrations of the structures as they now stand, and details of the testa. It was in the summer of 1903 that the Egyptian Guverndicat inued specifications suviting tenders and designs for three roads. bridges to be constructed over the Nile at Cairo. Por each bridge, thirty eight designs of tenders were received from thirteen firma, six of whom were French, one each German, Belgian, Italian, and Swiss, and three British, se of wbw submitted an American design. It will be seen that the competition was interna cional, and excited keen interest The Belgian torm alone submitted nine different designs for the large bridge, and three for each of the call bridges. As many as sixty to seventy drawings accompanied each tender, and in many cases general and detailed perspective drawings were attached to them. It w ati cated that the preparation of all the designs be represented an expenditure of about 25100V A mission was appointed to examine the designs and calculations and nsport to the Government. After a careful and prolonged examination of the various proposals the designs and tender of the joint firms of Sir William Arrol and Co, Limited of Glasgow and Mowers Head, Wrightson, and Co, Limited, of Middlesbrough, were scepted for construct in the three bridges, at a cost of 192.000% This result, continues "Bugineering was most gratifying, at a time when so much was being written about the inability of British facturers to compete with their Continental rivals The main bridge cross from Basel bear the road to the Pyramide to the Island of Rodah, and the two smaller bridges from Bodah Island to the main road leading to Old Cairu. The successful designs were prepared by the civil engineering staff of Sir William Arrol and Co., Limited. The main bridge in 1755 ft. in length between abutments, divided into 10 pas of 140ft, two ed spes of 70 ft. ad double-swing spar 220 ft. in length, with two clear openings of 66 it. The bridge is 20 metres in width, or 66 ft., between parapete divided into two footpaths ft. wide and roadway of so it in width, of which 16it is allocated to the tramways and 39 t to the roade The opening spas, adds "Engineering" is operated by two 30 brake horsepower electric motors setting through gearing on to the thok, sada be opened or closed in 3 minutes, including the time for all operations necessary in ob pectionwith the swinging The bridge have been officially tested by the Government with most satisfactory results. It is only necessary to quote from the late Sir Benjamin Baker reported your ago :-"As regarde material and workmanship, the bridge is entirely a tie factory, and in all respects the structure is fine example of the high class of work which CAD Dow be turned out by bridge builders of great experience, whose manufacturers are supplied with all the most modern appliances

div.head: Cholera Bulletin
div.p: A telegram from Djeddah announced 8 deaths from cholera in that town and 2 deaths from plague. 350 deaths from cholera are recorded from Mecca On the 9th inst, the deaths numbered 894.

div.head: The Mataleh Murder
div.p: The Cairo Parquet's enquiry into the cream stance of the Matarieb murder, shows that the three native soldiers who, after murdering Shaker El-Knousi, stole his money, consisting of cash and bills to the amount of £8,000 com united the crime with premeditation.

div.head: A.R.A.N.D.S.
div.p: A most successful dance was held last night at the Savoy Palace Hotel by the Alexandria and Ramleh Amateur Musical and Dristie Society, but owing to the pressure upon our space we are compelled to withhold the full report until tomorrow's issue.

div.head: The “Caronia”
div.p: The Cunard twin screw 8.8. "Caronia" sailed from Naples on Sunday morning and is expected here early this afternoon. She has many tourists on board, among whom are Mr. Schiff and family, Mr Tiffany and party, Wanamaker and party, Mr. Lehman, Mr Crittenden, Mt. W. Harry Brown and party, Mr. Burton and party, Mr. H. Alker and party, Mrs. Oliver Gail, Mr. Burden and family, and Mrs. Luckenbach

div.head: Theatre on Continental Railway
div.p: A company is being formed in Paris for the purpose of providing theatre cars for all the important express trains on the Continental li Be The railway the tree says the Stand'' correspondent, are to have 50 or 60 seats, a little stage, and an orchestra consisting of piano, fute, and a cornet. Passengers will book so directly the trains leave, in the same way as they uuw engage their tables in the dining car.

div.head: Theatrical Plays
div.p: In New-York as in London and in Egypt pieces are played in their original language One avoids more and more traductions which so often are ineffective This principle is the foundation itself of the Berlitz method of which the excellence has been proved by the univer success of the Berlite School. The Branches in Cairo and Alexandria-relatively new-are already very much appreciated as is proved by numerous testimonials. (Advt.).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION INCIDENT
div.p: EXPULSION OF A SHEIKH

Considerable discussion has been aroused in native circles by the treatment of Sheikh Razi, one of the ulema of the Al Azhar University at the last reception held by H H the Khedive. It is averred that the learned Sheikh was peremptorily ordered by the Grand Master of Ceremonies to quit the Palace and that instructions were issued to the soldiers of the Khedivial guard and to the police responsible for this gentleman's entrance to furbid bius Admission in the future. However this may be, the Sheikh left Abdin in high dudgeon and it can only be supported that the disfavour of His Highness was the cause of his expulsion. Abbas II is unlikely to have ordered the expulsion of an Alim from the Palace, above all on an occasion on which all the Moslem world is en fête, without good reasons and the report that Sheikh Razi had been guilty of proposing almost revolutionary measures dignified by enemies of the ancient and celebrated Moslem: University with the title of Schemes for reform'-which were highly displeasing to his fellow Ulems seems to us to restore some solid foundation. In any case we may be assured that H. H. the Khedive-who has in any case a perfect right to refuse to receive persons in wbom be bas no confidence is too far above the tumult of party strife and too inground in the pursuit not of his private but of the public interest, to have instructed his Grand Master of the Ceremonies to take any such action for merely personal reasons. At the same time we regret that no measures were taken to warn Sheikh Razi before the neweption that his presence at Abdin was not desired. for any such incident - which loses nothing in the telling-is to be regretted, more especially when it occurs under such conditions

div.head: DR. RUTHERFORD, M.P.
div.p: HIS DEPARTURE FROM EGYPT.

Dr. Rutherford, MP, left Cairo yesterday morning for Port Said in order to return home in time for the opening of Parliament. When leaving be cordially thanked his friends who came to the station to bid him farewell, for all the attentions that had been shown to him and for the beautiful and costly jewels sod treasures, which bis admirers had bestowed upon him. He also expressed his warm appreciation of the universal urbanity, with which he had been received by the British officials and the facilities afforded him by Dr. Dunlop sod bis eminent Anglo-Boption colleges for pouring his investigations into educational and other administrative mysteries. Mr. Rotberford spent Sunday on a visit to Mansonnab. He was specially struck with the ability and intelligence of Mustapha Pasha Maber, the popular Moudir tberg, whose intellectual capacity and liberal sympathie deeply impressed the Scotch Radical M.P. Here he noted, was at all events a B and an Egyptian, who was ripe for self-government. Dr. Rutherford. M.P., reflected that conceivably there might be many others like him, scattered throughout the length and breadth of the country, who had attained the same high level of mental capacity. From sub examples be derived mueb encouragement for bi pet theory that a larger share of Government and responsibility should be conferred upon the Egyptian people. Accompanied by the Moudit, the MP., visited the primary and technical schools, and made detailed and exhaustive inspection of these educational establishments. He also sawa girls sebool, which much pleased him. The want, however, of a secondary school at Mar south was strongly commented upon by him. Dr. Rutherford has been favourably impressed with all that he has seen, but his visit, so far as could be gleaned, has not obliged his political a priori intentions on the difficult theory of Egyptian Administration. He has made a deep study of Egypt in books and reports and has digested the voluminous an bual reports of Lord Cromer with amazing scrupulousness His fortnight's visit to this country will therefore give him . panoply for entering the arena of parliamentary debate fully primed to deal with every detail of Egypt in Administration, which comes before the notice of the House of Commons. He will be able to ask most searching questions about Egypt's internal organisation and will ply Sir Edward Grey with crucial problems to technical details of management and control Dr. Rutherford, M.P., is of somewhat reserved character and does not unburthe himself to the pertinacious interviewer However, as far as we can gather, the above represents our intelligent anticipation of what is likely to take place. There is a theory widely held among the ardent lative politicians

div.head: LORD CURZON (Gazette's Special Service)
div.p: London, Tuesday Lord Curzon has been elected an Irish peer hy a considerable majority.

div.head: CHRISTIANITY AND ISLAMISM.
div.p: The Rev. A. Connell, speaking at the Starlet's Missionary conference at Liverpool aid that Racial disturbances, misunderstandings and animosities were emerging at this critical moment and there was nothing more certain than that those animosities were going to affect the progress or the direction missionary work Christianity bad nothing o four from any of the great positive religions, except Islam. That faith had been ignored too long. Islam might rise in the Agony of despair for its last supreme struggle for dow inion amongst the races of mankind. All eyes were now turned to the Pacific, for Far Bastern problems overshadowed all others. Never had the Church greater opportunity to turn the energies of rebon civilization Godwards

div.head: THE CAIRO SEASON
div.p: SAVOY HOTEL DANCE.

It speaks well for the resource of the Savoy Hotel that on Saturday evening its management was able to serve the big banquet given by the Constitutional League to De Rutherford, M.P., which included covers for reventy in room at one end of the hotel at the same time that the usual number of Saturday dinner parties were in progress in the restaurant. The number in the latter place were even more numerous than usual extra tables being placed in another room leading out of the restaurant to accomodate the guests Miss Cochrane who generally entertains guests on Saturday nights had a larger party than usual: among them being Colonel and Mos Herbert Mr. and MrsRoyle Lady Oppenheim, Captain and Mn. Darell, Colonel Harvey Push, Colonel Cuthbert, Major Owen, Mr. & Mrs Clifford Hall Min Cochrane Mise Hocier, Mise Evelyn and the Moon Heywood Lady Barttelot’s table for eight included Captain and Mrs. Dunbar, Mr. and Schreiber, Miss Baird, Captain Lane and Mr. Byre. At Count Koti Brodsky's table were ibe Marquis Moravanti, Baron Villefangen Baron Hein, Donut Strassold, Band and Baroness Altred de Menas, Mr. and Mme de Zoltan, and Mr. de Waguer. With Mr. A B Gardner were Mr. and Mr. Sibthorpe Barlow, Mr. Adde, Mr. P. O. Gardner and others: Captain and Mrs Duffos were entertaining Mrs. and Miss Wholen. Mr. and Mrs Moncture Robinson, and Dr. Tribe Captain kennedy's party included Mrs. and Mis Park Lyle who have but lately returned to Cairo Major Haigh with Captain and Mrs Potagerald. Baron Polis de Me O had party of six*een, among whom were HE and Mme., de Martino Pasha Mr. and Mme Perdinand de Martino and Messrs. Leon and André Swarts Dining with Mma Emily Surock were Mme Boutros sod the Mesars. V. and A. Sanook. Mrs. de B. Carey bad s party with her. At another table were noticed Mr. Cetter Wilson with Captain Poller and Major Pereira Captain Bvaca also had a party, and Dr. and Mrs. Bouboulis were entertaining relatives. If any proof was needed to show how the son has improved of late, a glimpse into the ballroom later on would have been sufficient to convince pessimists that there is plenty of life even now in Cairo. It was perhaps the most festive function we have seen this winter, and we hear that some of the supper parties might still have been found in the restaurant till close upon three o'clock in the morning. There were some very noticeable toilettes to be seen during the evening, that of Mme Sersoek being especially bandrome. It was of emerald green chiffon, the skirt burdened with valves and heavily embroi dering with coloured bagles in floral design. The same bandsome garniture appeared on the corsage which was soft oned on the sleeves and shout the shoulders with lace. Wonderful emerald jewels bar monited with this gown Mme Zabar ww in white with elaborate jewelled embroideries about it; and Mme Boutros gown of deep suber was heavily embroidered with some silk Mrs. Park Lyle, was wearing a very handsome crown of grey chiffon weighted with effective embroideries of grey tissue and Mme Re chael Cattani's frock of grey was run with beautiful embroidery. Mn Maclean we weer ing princess robe of thick guipure lace, the scobertbe worn by Mrs. Knight with soft was applied with lovers knots of ale blue and pale heliotrope. Mrs. Stevenson was in an empire dress of thin white material trimmed with rouleaux of satin, the ceinture Inaped high at the book onder diamond buckle, while there were ornaments of sparkling silver about the front of the contage Mr. Molyneux was in Crosstin the bodice being continued in long panel down the front of the skirt One of the Miss York we in pretty frock of painted chiffon with black border, while the other bed on a lovely ress of white chiffon bearing panele lightly lismentee about it Mn Duffus frock of pink wt was run with multitudinous loops of DARROW pink ribbon very effective and most becoming Miss Pita Clarence was wearing dark blue set T spritted with chenille, the bodice and little Jeeves bearing bands of metallic blow insertion Miss Coles was in white bordered with rathers leep shade of blue and relieved with gold Mr Appleton's Black Velvet dress was of admirable and simple lines the corsage draped with black Maltese lace and showing a deep tucker run through with ribbon. Mrs Darell slno in black the black dress worn by Mim Felix Brown was relieved by bands of Painted satin ribbon which crossed the shoulders and formed a high draped us with long ends Miss Carey was in turquoise blue or pale green -the colours are almost indistinguishable by artificial light-the draped bodice being edged with glistening bande Princess Irene was in pink with embroideries lightly run with gold about the bodice. Misa Westrop was in white draperies of black chiffon. Mn Dunbar was wearing a cream satin gown very plain and simple but marvellously well out. Min Joneph was in white, glimpse of carpet shoes appearing be danced, Miss Davidson was in black met and Mine Coobrane who is passing the winter here with friend was wearing pale yellow and had rosettes of gold tissue in her hair heure were touches of scarlet showing to the dark wayes of Mise Nangovich's hair she was wearing a very dainty frock embroidered with tiny rose and long lines of opalescent sequins. Miss Barnes Lawrence was in blue, Miss Froom in an empire dress of pink, Miss Tuok in reseda green, Miss Leger in

frock of somewhat the same colouring Mrs. Acres was wearing a dull shade of blue relieved with gold dik embroidery, Mrs. Carrer in pale blue both Mrs. Williams and Miss Palmer were in Cream Miss Chase was in a cream satin princess robe Mrs. Tillard in figured chiffon, Miss Sumban in black with cream ribbon threaded through the con Last to be mentioned though among the first to be motions were Mme de Martino in bestifol Row of the parent back over white and Mode B. Carey in most becoming toilette of heliotrope velvet

div.head: WINTER RESORT RIVALRY
div.p: A correspondent write from the Riviera

The proprietors of the various health and pleasure morte here are making stresom effort to prevent fares in their power lies to do the soul rush to opt which sally takes place at about this time of the year. The fact that e bolers has appeared in the leaning Need upon excellent inducement to the tourist to postpone his departure from Europe but even before this dins had made its appearance there were dire tales of plague and death going the round of the Continental hotels even some of the shipping agents having so far to advise intending passengers to delay their departure as count of the terrible reports of plague just received 1 One can only imagine vaguely the inducements which must have been put before the eyes of such an agent before he could be brought to forego the profits which would seere to him in the natural way on every passenger who booked through his office. It is able to conclude that there must have been advantages of very exceptional value for the shipping agent, in addition to losing his ordinary profit of the moment, runs the risk of losing his deleted client for all time should the falsity of these statements be brought to light. But though these tales may, and undoubtedly do, carry a certain Amount of weight with the tourist who is vectoring to the Past for the first time they are powerless to impress the moved traveller, who indeed appears to regard them see recommendation to his favourite haunted inwoh if they lacked the chara which he has claimed for them over the attractions of the Continent there would be no need to make this attempt of belittling them. Last year it was the supported sod wholly imaginary danger of Native rising which was urged good and sufficient reason to the would be traveller to remain in Barope Then it was the plague bow it is the cholera What will it be nextil Let them go through the seven plagues of Egypt and still Ropt will hold the imagination and affections of the weekers after health and quiet who wander through the world in search of spot where the two na be som bined in a civilised country.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL SITUATION
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE”

Dear Sir,- A Cairo correspondent of the continental "Daily Mail," writing from Cairo in December, calls attention to the continuance of financial depression in Egypt and points out that the want of ready money is affecting all classes and nationalities in the country and continues "The fall in market values which met in last March has continued, land owners who sold their cotton early in the year have been paid only in part while in the share market securities which were quoted at £5 or £6 are now offered at about £1. Complaint is made in European business circles that the Banks are attempting nothing to relieve the situation. The Government is criticised for its passive attitude......... "The crisis has touched the national prosperity to a severe degree." All the above is most certainly true, and unfortunately there appears to be no prospect of affairs righting themselves as we anticipated in the new year. Rents continue to stand at exorbitant figures, living becomes more expensive daily, and money is as tight to-day as it was in the early days of the crisis. The banks refuse to make advances now on the security of stock to people whose signature would have been considered sufficient a year ago. To put the whole thing in few words every man doubts the financial stability of his neighbour with the result that a feeling of distrust prevails throughout the whole business community of Cairo, and until money is forced into circulation by some means or other there can be no prospect of renewed prosperity. There are rumours of the Government being called upon to relieve the situation by loan of two million to the country. It Is likely that the Government will consider a pro position of this kind, and if it did would the loan be of any real service to the country at large It would of course tend to keep things going for the time being, but would it be of any material assistance to the guarantee of financial security in the future. I for one doubt fit, it might keep the heads of several of our too numerous companies above water and it would certainly keep the rents at their present exorbitant standard. Would this be an advantage! I think not
Yours etc. Dourter
Cairo, January 19.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter

div.head: CYPRUS NOTES
div.p: (From our CORRESPONDENT)
Larnaca, January 16, 1908. Porta
Personalls

It is announced that Mr. A.C. Staart, who, for some four and a half years has been District Court Judges Papho is about to be transferred in the same city to Limano vioo Mr. JR Holmes who has been appointed to Nicosia in succession to Mr P. Parker. It is slee stated that Mr. Bros son of the London Stipendiary Magistrate is to replace Mt. Staart st Pabo Mr. Bros bus visited Cyprus on several consions during the last two years and is therefore no stranger to the place or the English community The Archdeacon and Mrs. Beresford Potter lost Cyprus today. They intend to stay a few days in Egypt and to break their journey homewards at Naples and Tunis, where they may spend a little time.
Sport

On Saturday the 11th instant, a paperebase Arranged, when upwards of 20 ladies and gentlemen met at Atbals or Nini A good ron ww enjoyed and the bars were only found by their parents at friendly to prepared for the whole party at the Atball ciftlik, where they were joined by Sir Charles and Lady King Harman
Bairsm Festivities

The Greek New Year and the first day of Kurban Bairsm happens to have fallen on the same day this year, and we have therefore bad the combined festival of both communities This naturally caused partial cowtion of official business on the 14th and an almost complete stoppage of general trade for two or three days As usual the Moslems and Greeks, but especially the former, have spent much of their holiday time in driving in and about the towns. This seems to be a specially popular form of amusement st such times and is generally accompanied by a small amount of shooting and singing On the occasion of the last Bairam several accidents occurred from furious driving, and earrings drivers have this year been warned against indalging in this practice under threat of the loss of their licenses.
Severe Weather
Snow has fallen again heavily on the South era range, throughout its entire length, and almost to the base of the mountains, and very old weather, though bright and clear, is now prevailing
Concert At Nicola

A grand concert was given on the 10th instant at the Papadopoullos Theatre, Nicosia, "In sid of Consumptive Pend." The performance was held under the patronage of his Excellency the High Commissioner and Lady King Harman, who were present. The boom was unfortunately, by no means full have seen it, but the expec could not have been heavy. It may be hoped that a ti fotory sum was nevertheless, realised to be placed to the credit of the Pand. The entertainment provided was good, and though not very varied in character, was very creditable to the small baglish community, who with one exception supplied the musical talent on the occasion. Particularly noteworthy was the really fine duet for two pianos most excellently played by Mr. G. Smith and Mo Ami rayan. The performance WM was almost faultless and both ladies excelled themselves and delighted the audience Mn. Bertram ng charm ingly, her rendering of "Should be upbraid" being immensely appreciated and provoking an encore. A violin solo by Miss I. Spencer, and a violin trio by Miss L. Spencer, Mr. Beknill and Mis I. Gore were welcome contributions and were much enjoyed and heartily appland ed. The programme was completed by excellent songs from Col. Gore, Capt. Durham Hall, Rev. F. LIEdwarda, and Mr. &. Since the existence of the Nicosia Pamagosta Railway it has become customary for Pema gusta residents to train to Nicosia for any entertainment of this sort and to return to their district theme night. This provides them with • pleasant opportunity of taking part in historical events at the capital and at the me time adds materially to the taking of any charitable performance
Annual Show

The annual Animal Show has today been held at the metropolis under the auspices of the Committee for the improvement of the Brood of Cyprus Stock. This event is molly fixed for Kourbam Bair , which, being a moveable feast occurring a fortnight earlier every year, has brought it about that this Show is now being held in the depth of the Winter. In course of time presumably thin feast will take place in the setumn instead of the winter, and the Animal Show Mociated with it will then fall close upon the Omodne Animal Show, which is regular fixture fre the 27th September. Doubtlen arrangement will be made to obviate this, but, under present conditions, not a few livestock owners must be deterred from showing their apmak by a reasonable objection to exposing them to the biting wind, which so often prevails, wit has done to day, at this time of year.
Zaptieh Sports

Tomorrow the Zaptieh Sports will be held, as usual, in the Most at Nicosia. This is very popular fixture and draws a large crowd. Invitations to test are out to leading persons and personal friends of the Police. officials, as in former years
N.R.N. The Duke of Connaught
The Kings Warrant appointing His Royal Highness the Duke of Connaught - Field

Marshal Commanding in China the British Troops And High Commissioner in the Mediter , be l ly published hers Of special interest to Cyprus are the worde directing that HR hall tako precedence of the Governor of Gibraltar and Maluk and the High Commissioner of Cyprus

"The Official Geretter of the soub instant notifies that medical inspection against arriva from Adalia soprel and similarly in the one of arrival from Beyrout. On the other hand al direct arrival from any part of the Red sea are to be subjected to five days quattine to be undergone at Lamas

div.p: Among the pengers due to morre bor ning by the "Hollopolis" are the Date and Duchou of Madrid, with waited 16, who have engaged apartments at the New Khedivial Hotel
Prince Waldemar of Promis bus arrived at Amouan, where he bus engaged ite of rooms at the Savoy Hotel for a long stay.
- Lews J. K. Watro Puhe Aide de Camp to the Kbedive, left Cairo for Lexor het night and will return to the Capital on Saturday morning
Chevalier de Martino, Italian Comel General, has arrived in Bopt and is staying At the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo

The Veo. Arodencos A Wand is leaving for Cairo tonight and will return to Alexandria to BOTTOM. Doring Aroederson Ward's shoe the Rev. F. P. Normas be will be responsible for the daty at St. Mark's Church
Womegret to announce the death at Cairo of Mr Sarah Maclardie Amos widow of the late Professor Sheldon And 61 year The funeral will take place at the new Pro toutant Cemetery, Cairo, at noon tomorrow
Ritter Maurice Domony de Domony, med his family, Director General of the Hungarian Steam Navigation Company has arrived from Budapest, and is staying at the Seminais Hotel, Cairo,
Mr. and Mrs. Hall Caines, are staying at the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo.
Mrand Mrs. P. G. Davidson are staying at the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo

We regret to announce the death of Captain Prederiok Seymour Blight of the Anchor 8.8. "Castalis" and late Commander of the 8.8 "Asyria" which occurred on the 16th inst The burial service conducted by Bishop Riley, who was a passenger by the “Castalia”
Mr. A G. Lawford is leaving Cairo for England today and will probably be absent for about a month
Mt. P. Hopkins of the Ministry of the Interior, transferred to the Ministry of Pinap, and Mr. B Burnett i rom tra ferred from the Ministry of Finance to the Loterior

J. Miall Mr . Solari, Mr. J.J. Palma Baron d'Betreil lis, Dr. Badano, Mr. Mitanchi, Mr. Porta Mr. Grein Bey, Mr. Erdmandoerfer, Mr. A W. div.head: LIVE-STOCK HAWKING.
div.p: “TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir,-Is there no authority in the city which can put a stop to the cruelty perpetrated under our very eyes? One constantly sees live pigeons, fowls, and ducks tied tightly by the legs hawked about the streets for sale. How long they are kept in this torture heaven alone knows, but the agony they must endure is undeniable. This day in the Rue Cherif Parba I saw a native offering for sale on 19 or 15 live wild ducks tied in benches by the lege with cord sad slang over beholder Presumably some of these wretched bride would remain in this position the whole day and being wild their leg wooldsboetied until some prohor bad pait need to their offerings Baskets made from the items of palm le you are within the road of all hati and Invention to think that if there be my Authority with power to omog roh order no native should be allowed to hawk live birde or simal except in baskets of suitable size
Yours faithfully
Alexandria, January 21, 1908
